segments.text: This is Frank Toback.
Tonight I'm at the home of John Groff in San Antonio, Texas.
The date is August 20th, 1984.
I'd like to start off this interview with just a little bit of background information on you as far as where you were born and when.
I was born in Ryan Park, Wyoming, which was a ranger station at the time.
April 4, 1941.
When my father joined the Army Air Corps in the Second World War, my family moved to Montrose, Colorado after the war, and then the rest of the
I—all my schooling was in Colorado, in Leadville, Durango, and I went to college at Western State College of Colorado.
How old were you when you all moved to Montrose?
I think I was eighteen months old.
Oh, so you were just a baby then.
Yes.
What did your father's occupation in Colorado—
He was a forest ranger, graduate of the University of Oregon with B.S.
in forestry.
What about your mother?
What was she like?
She was a school teacher.
My parents got married, I believe, in Delta, Colorado.
When she was teaching school, my father was foreshadowing today.
Were you all religious at all?
No, not very much.
Well, where did you go to college again?
Western State of Colorado, which is at Gunnison, Colorado.
one of the cold spots in the country.
What made you decide to join the Army?
It was right during the Cuban Missile Crisis, which was in October of 1962 and I joined in November.
Actually it came about that I wasn't—I had three years of college and I wasn't worried progressing very well and so I decided to lay out a year and I was going to take a trip around the world.
And I was going to try to get down to Australia and work for a year there and then continue on.
to work in Australia you have to be a citizen or apply for citizenship and I didn't want to give up my American citizenship so that sort of went by the wayside.
At the time I was a smokejumper for the Forest Service up in the state of Washington.
What were your duties as far as that?
What was that, smokejumping?
We fought forest fires and the way we fought forest fires was jumping out of airplanes and landing by parachute and fight forest fires.
And it was a very good paying job and first year I was a smokejumper.
I made enough money to buy a new car and put me through a year of school.
That's cool.
So it was a good summertime job.
Yeah, sure.
It was a lot of work, but.
Yeah, it's a little worth it.
I'd like to talk a little bit about your military training.
When you first joined the Army, where were you located?
Where did you first locate here at?
My basic training was at Fort Ord, California, and then I went through advanced individual training there also in communications.
How long was the boot camp last?
I really don't remember, I guess it was about three months.
What was it like?
Just an ordinary boot camp?
I had a friend from Montana.
We used to get up before revelry and run
four or five miles before Reveille.
We got caught doing it.
They wanted to know why—we weren't supposed to be out of the barracks at that time—so they wanted to know why and we told them we weren't getting enough exercise and basic training.
It didn't make them very happy.
When did you decide to join the Special Forces?
Well, when I enlisted it was my idea to join the forces.
a consideration—well, they couldn't guarantee me being in the forces, but they could guarantee me on my enlistment if I didn't make jump school, my enlistment was void then.
And after I got through my individual training, I went to Fort Gordon, Georgia and went through jump school there.
When I was at Fort Ord they put me through the barrier of tests for the special forces which I passed very highly.
In fact, I had the highest test score that they ever saw.
They called me in to find out why I made such a high test.
The testing was sort of interesting.
What they would do is they would give you about anywhere from fifteen to forty-five minutes of tape recording of a situation and then you had to answer questions in say like

oral questions that they gave you and you had five choices here was excellent good fair bad or well was five choices like that and and they were asked a question with an answer and then you had to put down how you rated it and
Total score, maximum score of the test was six hundred, and at that time you had to have three hundred to pass it, and I made over five hundred and fifty on the test.
Fantastic.
So I think it was the first time that anybody ever broke five hundred, so they really pumped me, and it was basically quick
critical decision test.
In other words, the questions came to you so fast you had to make a critical decision very fast, this is what they want.
So spontaneous.
Yeah.
Why did you decide to become a medic?
It seemed like it had the most interest to it.
I always
Well, when I grew up, the way I grew up was sort of old fashioned.
You always helped your neighbor and you always, if somebody needed help, you always helped them out.
So, I figured I could be the most help this way.
Were there any medics, out of the medics, were there any of them
conscientious objectors.
Did you ever run across any?
No.
How were—in your military training, did they prepare you at all for the type of warfare that you would see in Vietnam?
Very good.
Very good.
I had about two and a half years training before I went over there, and my medical training
was at the degree where—they said we were equal to a doctor twenty years before—was how much training we had.
We were able to do surgery, diagnose, prescribe medicine, which we did do very much.
Now, in the war,
When you went to Vietnam, when and what year did you go and where did you arrive in Vietnam at?
I went over with Fifth Special Forces, which was the first permanently assigned unit in Vietnam, which our tour agility was one year.
always before.
Normally when somebody went over to Vietnam they went over on what they called a temporary duty station, which could be up to six months.
And they moved the whole group, which was sort of unusual, was over to Vietnam and the fifth stayed there
They started going over in 1964 and was completed probably in 1964 or 1965.
The whole group was there and they stayed there until probably about 1978, I believe it was.
When you were first going over to Vietnam, what did you see as America's role there in Vietnam?
A way I saw the role of the Special Forces was mainly as a teacher.
Officially, our assignment was to recruit local people, train them, arm them,
and advise them on military and other matters in their area.
And this not only took in Vietnam, but all of Southeast Asia.
And we often went into, a lot of the teams went into what is called the mountain yard areas.
and they had very good results with most of the mountain yards.
What were the mountain yards?
The mountain yards in Southeast Asia was equal to our American Indians.
They lived in
Vietnam for hundreds of years, and they were probably the only—the most native people, like our American Indians was in the Americas, to Southeast Asia.
And they were fierce, independent, small tribes, and most of them never got conquered by the

people who conquered that land for several thousands of years and they were mainly like our American Indians, hunters, wanted to keep their own religion and society isolated in mountain areas and they just didn't like to fool with them.
What were your immediate thoughts when you first got in country?
Well, we landed in Saigon.
We flew over from North Carolina to Saigon and I couldn't believe the mass of people in Saigon or the smell.
What was that like?
If you've ever been in a smelly part of Mexico, you know.
You know, open sewers and garbage out in the street and everything else.
Not real pleasant.
No.
How long did you stay in Saigon?
just a few days, and then we went up to the Special Forces, the 5th Headquarters, which was in Nha Trang, and there we got our assignment.
We were previously assigned, and the area we were supposed to go into was at the corner of Vietnam, Cambodia, and

And we were supposed to go in and recruit the mountain yard tribe by name of Jew, J-E-W, which were discounted by the other mountain yards as the savages, which you would compare to the, I guess, the Apaches of American Indians.
After we got there we got another assignment as usual in the Army and instead of going in that area we went about three hundred miles south in the Mekong Delta.
Did you ever have any dealings with our ARVN troops?
Yes.
What was your opinion of them?
We had the highest camp in Fourth Corps, which was the Mekong Delta, and we had the first airborne ranger company of the Vietnese troops, and they were top notch.
They were really good, and they were probably one of the oldest units in the Vietnam Army, and they were excellent fighters.
What was the age of the average Arden soldier?
The age of their varied greatly.
In fact, as I was saying before our interview started that there was three of them that were veterans of the Battle of Bindinfu and on both sides.
So they had experience?
Yes, very much.
They were very good fighters.
They were good as any American's troops on the whole I would say.
What was your feelings as far as the South Vietnamese people?
Did you feel that they really wanted to win their war?
Were they really dedicated to this cause?
I feel like the South Vietnamese people on the whole
They just wanted to have peace and be able to live and have a family, just like we do today.
There's no difference.
The area I was in was wild rice.
In other words, when the Mekong River flooded during the monsoons, it covered the ground and they planted their rice.
And then they harvested, and there was no dikes or anything like that.
And of course, all the land was owned by absentee landlords, which probably never saw the land.
And I would say the average income of the farmer there was probably ten, twelve dollars a year in American money.
So they were extremely poor.
But then you have to understand that this was in the tropics and about the only thing they would raise most of their fruits and vegetables or pick them wild and raise some chickens and hogs.
This was self-sufficient.
Yes, very much like our frontier farmer.

How was your feelings towards the Viet Cong and the North Vietnamese Army in comparison to— I didn't have much contact with the North Vietnamese Army because they didn't really come down there in full strength, but the Viet Cong that were in our area
were very poorly equipped and as far as weapons go and so on and they were—just the political arm was well organized.
Their units were not very well organized and when we ran into it we generally always had a better hand.

saying this too that don't forget that we recruited people from the local population and trained them under combat conditions and our troops weren't that good either but it seemed like that we were able to now in our camp we also had what was called

We were supposed to advise them and they were supposed to advise the soldiers, but actually we were—it was the American money that paid for the soldiers that were in our camp and we did most of the planning and operations and so on.
And they were more or less
intermediaries and—but they—most of the Wukong Dai Bek were well-trained and well-disciplined soldiers.
I'd like to switch gears and talk a little bit about your unit that you served with.
What was your feelings toward your unit?
Well, we were a maverick unit by the word go.
The superior corps of our unit was extremely high.
We have a chapter here of the Spatial Forces Association, the Alamo chapter.
For example, how our unit operated, we have two Medal of Honor winners in our chapter.
there's 88 members right now.
So, it's—our unit expected—it was expected of us to have the—to do the best, and I would say probably 99 percent of the time that's what was given.
being you were a medic, did it make any difference as far as your relations with the other guys?
Or, you know, was there any problems as far as them cooperating with, you know, taking medicines and stuff like this?
Did that get in the way of your friendship with them or the love for them or anything?
No.
Of course, I had the responsibility of the—approximately of the team
There was two medics there, and I was a junior medic, but my senior medic did not like to work in medicine, so it was all turned over to me, which I was very happy with.
And he was free to do other duties, and he was more interested in weapons.
Now, someone who went over to Vietnam to be what is called free-qualified,

you had to be qualified in three of the fields of the special forces, which was, I was, my main qualification was medic, and then they had communications, weapons, demolition engineering, and communications.
And I was qualified in four, which was intelligence, demolition, and
communications.
Normally, when we went out on patrol, two of us would go out together.
In other words, you covered each other's back.
It didn't matter which field you were in, when it was your time to go out to patrol, you did.
Of course, I probably went out more than anybody else because
A lot of my work was also in what we commonly call pacifications, civil affairs, or propaganda.
And I thought I was very good, and I used my medical one, not only to help the people, but also in these fields.
And it ended up in an area, we went in and we built a new camp
which was 95 percent VC area.
And I was the only one that the people trusted, so I was the one that set up all the local intelligence there, because they would only talk to me.
They wouldn't talk to any other Americans.
Well, that's amazing.
It was later in—I know you were there in
As the war went on in later years, the Army came out with reports that there had been a few problems in the Army of mainly fragging, drug abuse, and self-inflicted wounds.
Was there ever any problems with this that you saw?
Maybe not in your unit, but maybe at all.
No, none.
One of the guys on our team
claimed to have migraine headaches, and he wanted certain medication for it, which was very strong medication.
I wouldn't give that unless he saw our doctor.
See, we had a doctor for each company, which is very unusual, and a medical officer, a regular MD.
I felt like if he had that bad of headaches, he should see somebody better than I was.
And so I would not give him the medicine.
So an interesting thing was that about every three months I had to give the team shots.
And one of the shots was gamglobium, 10 cc's, which is a big shot.
And you only can give 5 cc in each cheek of the butt.
And to get around the argument of that, I called in, I would take the shots over to my CO and tell him it was time for shots and drop his drawers.
And he would butt around and I would inform him that I was the one that was in charge of the medical thing and he better do it.
And so he did.
Then after he got the shots, I asked him to get the rest of the team together and it was no problem.
In fact, they used to draw straws who gave me my shots.
I imagine they all enjoyed that.
Yes.
But we had about four or five qualified medics in the team, so it was not only—our team
count the young team, the average age was twenty-three, but in the team they already had fourteen missions in Vietnam.
But it was an experienced team.
What was your impressions of other units?
When you say other units, that covers a whole gamut.
Well, just other units maybe within the 5th Special Forces that you dealt with that you were in contact with.
Well, the 5th Special Forces had several different specialized units.
One of them was the Mike Force, which was—they were to go into
areas like when a camp was being overrun and try to save it and things like this.
Or if they got some good intelligence to lay a trap for a large body of a Viet Cong.
These were extremely outstanding units.
And then they had recon units that were also extremely good.
what they went through for the physical and endurance and what they did was exceptional.
A lot of people won't admit it, but I know there was—we even had teams that was in North Vietnam.
So it seems like they had it run down by specialties very much.
Yes, I would say like the Mike Force and these recon units and so on, that they were the elite of the special forces.
I can't say how much—I don't think I could have made one of those units.
I wasn't physically strong enough or my endurance wasn't enough to go into it.
What was your impressions of the higher command and higher echelons?
I think as time goes on I'll find out that this was a political war and conventional soldiers should have never went into Vietnam.
My feeling is that, and the main idea
The main feeling that I knew of the Special Forces, most of the people in there, felt like, first of all, they should leave it to units like the Special Forces to help the people there.
But to do that, what we had to have was massive land reforms and to let the local people own their own land, and then they would be very willing to defend it
And if this happened, I think it would have been a free country now.
And instead of going in there with the massive—and then too, the other thing they did wrong was search and destroy, which was just extremely wasteful.
They did not avoid taking hold in areas and
You could never find everything that was an area when you went in there for search and destroy.
I'd like to shift gears just a little bit now and have a little background on your unit and talk about your first encounter with the enemy.
What was your thoughts and reactions when you first—your first confrontation with him?
I don't even remember.
It just happened.
Yeah.
With the training we had, it just happened.
We were so well trained that you did things automatically.
I would like to put into something about the medics of the Spatial Forces.
Three classes I went through—the class before mine, my class, and the class behind me—I believe I'm the only survivor of the classes.
And that's how great of casualties the medics had because when somebody got hit, they went and got them.
And that was part of our training.
Did it without hesitation or without thought?
That's right.
What were, as the war went on, what was the causes of most of the injuries?
About seventy percent were from booby traps and mines and things like this.
And the Viet Cong would put these
indiscriminately over certain areas.

We also used the advantage—I know one village was around the Cambodian border that we never were able to get into that we knew was a Viet Cong depot because they had a two-lane paved highway coming in from Cambodia and stopped right there at
And this is where the Kaikai River went south toward Saigon and didn't take anybody with any great imagination why the road stopped there, right there at the river.
And about a K and a half or about a mile inside the border, we built our camp right on the banks of the Kaikai River to stop the infiltration.
And we were not liked very well by the Viet Cong for doing this.
In a confrontation, how was it decided as far as what injuries were treated given top priority or was there any of this sort of thing?
Probably the worst

uh, action we had, I had, uh, 16 seriously or critically wounded and which I evacuated eight of them, uh, to, to the hospitals and, uh, all 16 I was, I was treating or, or I got, they, uh, they got to me alive
or I got to them and none of them died until after I reached the hospital.
And the priority was I was able to handle that Maine.
And it was sort of an interesting thing.
I have open-handed policy about medical treatment.
I would treat anybody and no questions asked.
And I know I treated a lot of Viet Cong when they thought they could not save their life, they brought them to me.
And I know it.
But I treated them and the majority of them did die.
And they were just too far gone, there was nothing you could do.
But this, to point out something else,
the respect that the enemy had of me, I had a twenty-five thousand dollar bounty on my head.
And at that time the airplane pilots only had ten thousand, so if you count how good a job you did by what your enemy thought of you, you can use that as a yardstick.
What was the extent of the treatment in the field?
Well, there was two diseases that I could not treat, and that was TB and leprosy.

On the whole, I was told that I should not enter any of the three major cavities in surgery, and I did not, but at one time I thought possibly I would have to, because we had an American that came down with, excuse me, with either appendicitis or

I diagnosed it as penicillus and we were socked in from the weather for four days and I treated him with antibiotics for the four days and finally was able to evacuate him out and when he got to the hospital he couldn't find anything wrong with him so I um
cured appendicitis with the use of antibiotics.
What were the major diseases that you encountered?
Malaria was very prevalent.
TB was also, and I would say probably eighty percent or more of the population had one or both.
And the first week I was at our first camp, which was Don Phuc, I had four old—or five—I guess it was five old people die on me from pneumonia.
And the trouble was that when they were brought to me, I could cure the pneumonia, but they were so
far down with the disease that their body could not come back and they died because of basically no nourishment and what the disease did to their bodies.
Was there any problems as far as the American soldiers had adjusting to the climate?
Was there ever any heat stroke?
Yes, there was.
When you consider that during our wintertime, which was a dry season, it probably never got under 90 degrees where we were, and you really had to push the salt tablets and water all the time.
I know I was evacuated out of the area three times for a year.
combat exhaustion or, you know, of a heat, and probably a combination of the two.
Most of the time when I was at the camp, I'd put in anywhere from—an easy day would be sixteen or eighteen hours.
And this went for seven days a week.
And when you—the Americans normally pull guard
on the Americans, but we pulled guard on the whole camp because inside our camp we figured at least fifteen percent of our troops were Viet Cong.
And then we had daily operations and then normally night ambushes that you went out for all night and things like this.
It really made some long days.
Was there any venereal disease at all?
I know a lot of armies in the past wars have had problems with this.
No, most venereal diseases were in the larger seas.
In Saigon.
Mm-hmm.
As far as having an intimate relationship with any of the local population, that was a very strict no-no, and none of our team did.
Mm-hmm.
Although at one time I did have four nurses working under me and one of the nurses would not hesitate to go out on two weeks patrol with me and carry a weapon and everything.
I had some very good Vietnamese nurses I trained or the people before me trained and they were excellent.
What sort of preventive measures were there for like malaria?
We took some pills once a week that was supposed to prevent malaria.
As far as I know, none of my team came down with malaria.
But you could not prevent malaria in the local population.
The only thing you could do is treat it when it came up.
How did you treat it?
With different kinds of medication.
Okay.
You had said that you had an open-door policy.
What was the amount of patients that you treated, the doctor-to-patient ratio?
Well, like I said before, I felt like our main object of going into Vietnam was to be teachers.
Anytime I found somebody who was interested in medicine, I grabbed ahold of them and made a medic or a nurse out of them and taught them as much as I could.
And I would say for approximately the eleven months I was there, sometimes with sending out different groups for sick call, in other words, a nurse would go out and have a sick call, maybe
half a mile away from the village and so on, that sometimes I would have up to my medical teams and I would see up to 500 people a day for sick call.
See, we were the only—I was the only modern medicine in the whole province.
It was approximately 17,000 people in the province.
That is unbelievable.
And then I had—
the twelve Americans and approximately six hundred Vietnese soldiers that were there.
But used them, like I said before, used the medical field very much as a weapon against the Viet Cong.
If you want me to expand on that?
Yeah, if you would.
At this one village up close to the Cambodian
One day we went up there with our idea in hand and about three hundred yards from the village I set up a sick call station.
And when the word got to the village I started seeing people from the village there.
And it wasn't very—about half an hour later or so on that Viacom came down there
in force with the idea to drive us out.
And of course we retreated back towards the camp and we knew there was the field right next to the river there was full of mines.
So we had to stay behind ambush.
That's why it is that when I was there they got in position and we walked right through them and when the Viet Cong came they opened up on
and drove him into the minefield and we could hear some mines going on and so we went back and
